I lost my wife and my son has been left in critical condition by the hospital here,” Hansda narrated his plights.

Title: People misbehave with corona warriors again, man arrested in city
Article:
Misbehaviour of people with the frontline workers fighting with Coronavirus is not stopping and was witnessed at Teelajamalpura where three BMC employees who went senitising the area faced threats and offensive behavior by a 40-year-old man who was later arrested by Teelajamlapura police.

The victims Shoaib Siddiqi along with Dharmendra and Gyan Singh have gone sanitisation of area and when they reached Near Krishna Public School the accused identified as Nalin Rawat confronted the victims and alleged that they are spreading Coronavirus after which the victims showed their ID cards provided by BMC still Nalin continued to threaten them and asked to leave the area. Based on the complaint lodged by Shoaib police detained the accused who revealed that he had asked the three to leave the area.

Police have registered a case under section 188 of the IPC and section 51 of Disaster Management Act against the miscreant and was arrested in the matter. Shoaib in his complaint stated that after spotting them accused asked for AADHAR card and when they showed ID cards of BMC he started to misbehave.

They tried to make him understand that they came for sanitizing the area which has been operationalize by BMC still accused continued with his nuisance.

Title: Virus showing no signs of let-up
Article:
Two new patients of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) were reported in Uttarakhand on Sunday. These two patients are residents of Dehradun and are reported to have come in contact with Tablighi Jamaat followers. With them the number of COVID-19 patients in the state increased to 44 .

Meanwhile two patients of the disease were discharged from the hospitals after recuperating from the dreaded disease on Sunday. With them the number of patients who have recovered from the disease in the state has reached to 11.

The two patients found positive for the disease are residents of Azad Colony in Dehradun and are said to be natives of West Bengal. Both of them were kept in institutional quarantine at Bidholi, Paundha since April 11. The authorities shifted them to Government Doon Medical College (GDMC) hospital after their samples were found positive for the disease.

The additional secretary, medical health and family welfare department, Yugal Kishore Pant said that out of 11 patients who have been discharged from hospitals so far after recovering from the disease, eight are from GDMC hospital and one each from Military Hospital (MH) Dehradun, Base hospital Kotdwar and Base hospital Almora. He said that all these discharged patients have been kept under quarantine in their homes for 15 days as a precautionary measure. Pant added that the work of contact tracing of the positive patients is on a war footing. He informed that reports of 336 suspected patients were received by the department on Sunday till 6.30 pm and out of them two were found positive while 334 were found negative for the disease. He said that reports of 255 samples are still awaited. The authorities have so far taken swab samples of 3344 suspected patients for COVID-19 test. On Sunday, samples of 183 suspected patients were taken and sent to the lab for test. A total of 2153 people are under institutional quarantine while 516 suspected patients are in hospital isolation in the state. The authorities have kept 64004 people under home quarantine in different parts of the state.

He added that 10 COVID-19 positive patients are currently admitted in GDMC hospital while 13 are undergoing treatment at government medical college Haldwani. Seven patients are admitted in Mela hospital, Haridwar and one MH Dehradun.

Title: Sub standard PPE kits for Corona warriors?
Article:
Even as the health and sanitation workers have plunged themselves into peril by remaining at frontline of war against the spread of novel Coronavirus (COVID-19), irregularities have come into fore in the purchase of all important Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) kits for them. In purchase of PPE, the health department and the administration of medical colleges of the state have flayed the norms set up by the Union Government and have kept aside the orders of state administration.

These irregularities got surfaced after the doctors of the government medical college found the PPE kits sub standard and returned them. After getting information of the irregularities, the state administration has banned purchase of PPE kits at district level. The Uttarakhand High Court (HC) has also taken cognizance of a PIL questioning the quality of PPE kits and sought response of officials concerned by April 21.

It is learnt that the officials purchased sub standard kits from unlisted vendors and suppliers which didn’t had the necessary approval by authorised laboratories.

As per the Government of India guidelines, there are only two officially recognised laboratories for conducting tests on body overalls (PPE) in India, the South India Textile Research Association (SITRA), Coimbatore and Defence Research and Development Establishment (DRDE), Gwalior

After the enforcement of the nationwide lockdown by the Prime Minister Narendra Modi on March 22, the central government issued an advisory to the states regarding PPE kit and other medical equipment needed in battle against COVID-19. As per the advisory, the Public Sector Undertaking, Hindustan Latex Limited (HLL) was made a nodal agency for procurement of these materials.On March 24, the secretary medical health and family welfare, Nitesh Jha issued orders to health department and Principals of the medical colleges and asked them to purchase the equipment through HLL.

However the health department and medical colleges ostensibly purchased sub standard PPE kits for their frontline Corona warriors bypassing the procedure of getting them through HLL.

It is learnt that at many places, the health workers were shocked to find HIV kits instead of PPE kits.

The HIV kits are knee length only and are open from back. The PPE kits on the other hand are mandated to be made up of fluid and virus resistant material.

It has an overall, face mask, eye covers, N-95 masks, gloves, shoe cover and disposable bags. A kit once used had to be discarded. When The Pioneer tried to contact the director general (DG) of health services, Dr Amita Upreti over phone, the call went unanswered.

Title: No containment now in 2 places
Article:
The district administration on Sunday lifted the containment zone order that was imposed on two places after three persons tested positive for COVID-19 in Bhadrak district.

Bhadrak Collector Gyana Ranjan Das announced the relaxation through a Twitter post. Reportedly, additional restrictions imposed in Containment Zone 2 (Charampa) and Zone 3 (Erein) were removed.

The move came after two patients infected with COVID-19 recovered from the disease.

Earlier on April 15, the district administration had lifted containment restrictions at Puruna Bazaar in the district following recovery of a COVID-19 patient.

However, the lockdown restrictions would continue, said Das.

Title: 9 persons arrested on charge of gambling, Rs 42,200 cash found
Article:
Koh-e-Fiza police arrested 9 persons on the charge of gambling and recovered Rs 42,200 cash, playing cards from their possession in Halalpura on Saturday.

On the receipt of the information that gamblers are betting at Sai Pooja apartment in Sawan Nagar police team rushed to the spot and raided the place where nine persons were found gambling. The house was taken in the name of tattoo training by Naresh Kewlani who is also booked along with the gamblers.

Police said that the in the raid the gamblers were found gambling in flat no. S-1 and in the raid around Rs 42200 cash was recovered from their possession.

The call record details of the mobile phones recovered from the accused would be investigated.

The details of the gamblers nabbed would be investigated in the further investigation who were idendtified as Pankaj Nathani alias Panku (28), Hitesh Thadani(28), Palash Ramchandani(28) , Nikki Lekhwani(25), Hitesh Chandani(29), Saurav Vaswani (30), Dheeraj Gehani (26), Ashish Sevakani (27) and Bharat Tolani (26). The nabbed gamblers are resident of Bairagarh and involved in businesses.

The crime record of the accused could not be ascertained and Bairagarh police would be asked to shed information.

Police have registered a case under Gambling Act against the accused.

Apart from the Gambling Act the accused were also booked under sections 188, 269 and 270 of the IPC.

Police would also investigate that the gamblers managed to reach and gather at the place by crossing the checking done at several place.

Title: 10 Cuttack hospitals declared ‘Fever Clinics'
Article:
10 private hospital in Cuttack have been notified as “Fever Clinics” in view of rising positive cases of Covid-19 in the State

General public having flu-like symptoms like fever, cold, cough, difficulty in breathing are advised to visit only these private hospitals, in order to avoid the contamination of deadly virus. As part of precautionary measure, Cuttack Collector Bhawani Shankar Chayani has issued an advisory related to this issue.

The hospitals declared as “Fever Clinics” are Sun Hospital, Tulsipur, Shanti Memorial Hospital, Thoria Sahi Sabarmati General Hospital, Mahanadi Vihar, Sadguru Medical, Jagatpur, Chanakya Hospital, Canal Road, Ranihat, Om Shubham Hospital, Canal Road, Ranihat, Srusti Hospital, Mangalabag, Gudluck Hospital, Kathagola Sahi, Rudra Hospital, Bhanpur and Shakti Sai Hospital, Salipur

The Cuttack administration has advised other hospitals not to treat patients suffering from flu-like symptoms.

Title: Mountaineers make screen mask with stationary items
Article:
Unique initiative of two youngsters of Madhya Pradesh have brought a hope in society. The mointaineers Shobhit Sharma and Megha Parmar have prepared screen seat mask using stationary items.

It is made to help people in Corona pandemic. Megha Parmar said that the entire mask is prepared with the total expenditure of Rs 10. She informed that the same thing costs Rs 200, but we have made this in lowest cost to help people.

She further informed that it has been prepared using only one elastic, 40 cm of rubber, polis participial film and double side tape have been used.

This unique innovation has been done by them, inspiring many people across the country and making masks everywhere are giving by making this screen sheet mask, they have given it to our brave soldiers who have stood firm to protect us, like the time of Corona, our police officer cleaning staff have been made and distributed from their pocket money at home to the doctor.

All masks is being used, and it is much appreciated, while the police force is making such mask screen sheet mask with many other resources and the innovation of this mask is being appreciated everywhere when Megha and Shobhit were asked this idea where When he came from, he told that when we sincerely want that we help someone, there is some solution from somewhere, we were sitting in the house.

Both of them wanted to help people, then come this Dia Shobhit Nath Sharma when it came to idea they have it named after making scheme seat masks. This masks can be reused by cleaning it with sanitizer other day. They have distributed among police officers and doctors.

Title: Antibody Rapid test conducted in BBSR
Article:
With Bhubaneswar emerging as the hotspot of the coronavirus spread in the State, antibody rapid tests for detection of COVID-19 commenced in the city on Saturday.

Health and Family Welfare Department said, “It is a serological test. Blood is taken from the vein and the result can be known in 15-30 minutes. This test is being done primarily for the purpose of surveillance.”

Meanwhile the Chief Secretary in a tweet said that, “More than 2,500 samples were collected from the people, who participated for mass COVID19 testing in three days under the initiative ‘BhubaneswarStrategy’.”

Initially, COVID warriors or persons on active duty such as healthcare workers, police force, sanitation workers, delivery personnel, vegetable vendors, milk booth owners, as well as people living in containment zones and nearby slums are being covered on priority for rapid tests.

Testing is being organised by the Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation and the Health Department. The department has requested the residents of the city to contact their Resident Welfare Associations, ANMs, ASHA Workers and Ward Officers to avail testing in a smooth manner.

Collection of nasal and throat swabs for RT-PCR test would continue for all contacts of positive cases, all SARI and ILI cases, all persons with flu-like symptoms and all high-risk asymptomatic cases throughout the State including Bhubaneswar.

Title: Pool campus drive on at RT University
Article:
A virtual pool campus drive of the international recruitment and staffing company "Mind Lens" is currently being organized. It is being organised in Rabindranath Tagore University.

On Sunday, it was the second day of virtual csmpus drive. Various students from different branches participated in virtual drive.

These efforts of the university will provide employment opportunities to the students. University's Training and Placement Officer Mr Abhishek Shroti told that for campus drive of 'Mind Lens', B.C.A., M.C.A., B.E. (CS, IT), B.C. A large number of students of pharma have registered.

The selection process will be done through Telephonic and Skype. Along with this, online training is being provided for second and third year students for skill development. All students are being given work from home internships.Sanjeev Gupta, Dean Academics of the University, said that the possibilities of online placement of students of all the courses of the university are being explored on a large scale.

Companies are also sharing their demand for online recruitment with the university. University Registrar Vijay Singh informed that our aim is to provide maximum facilities to the students using the latest technology. In this sequence, the university is conducting online placements for final year students.

He said that the last round of negotiations with several companies were going on. Presently, in the changing scenario of education, the university is constantly striving to protect the interests of students by using various virtual and online platforms for placements.

Rabindranath Tagore University faculty and students have entered the virtual era in the event of a lockdown during the Corona virus crisis.

Online studies at the university continue unabated. Faculty lectures, tutorials and assignments are being given to students through online apps. With these efforts of the university, students are able to complete their studies even in the event of lockdown.

Title: Kalinga Hospital provides telemedicine service
Article:
To assist patients to reach out to their doctors with ease during the lockdown period, doctors at the BR Life Kalinga Hospital here have come up with a new service of giving medical consultations over phone.

The hospital has now come up with the facility of telemedicine where the patients who are keen to inquire about their health ailments or need assistance in their disease management can call the hospital, the hospital has announced. Any person seeking medical consultations can reach out to the qualified doctors of the hospital. Citizens can use the toll-free numbers of the hospital to get an expert advice. They can call on the numbers-18005724000. Patients are also provided facility to get video consultation with the doctors through the toll-free number and an additional number of 7205317607.

Title: 3.85 lakh under community surveillance in Dehradun
Article:
With Dehradun reporting 22 of the total 44 COVID-19 cases in the state so far, the district administration has continued to keep more than three lakh people under community surveillance. On the directions of Dehradun district magistrate Ashish Kumar Srivastava, till now the teams of teachers, Asha workers and Anganwadi workers have done the work of community surveillance of around 3,85,226 people. Informing more about the surveillance, the Dehradun Chief Development Officer (CDO) Nikita Khandelwal said that two types of surveillance are being carried out by the administration.

The first type is community surveillance which is being carried out by the teams of Asha workers, Anganwadi workers and teachers who directly interact with the suspected patients of COVID-19 especially in the red zone areas like Bhagat Singh Colony, informed Khandelwal.

The second type of surveillance is being done through phones with the help of data available to the administration, added the CDO. On Sunday, 37 teams contacted 202 people through phones. However, only one local was found with the symptoms of cough and cold among other symptoms by the community surveillance team which is quite less than on the other days. As per the officials, the medical team has been informed about it.

Title: CM compliments people for lockdown support
Article:
Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel said on Sunday while addressing the people of the state that the discipline, strength and grit shown by the people, to tackle the Corona crisis, since last one month, are unique.

He said in his address, Rs Rs just a month before, I sought your cooperation by addressing you in a similar way, to deal with the corona virus crisis. Telling the truth, when I was appealing to you for your support for the first time to take preventive actions for spread of Corona virus, I had many apprehensions. It was not an easy task to ask the crores of people of such a large state to follow the changes in their way of life, business, conduct etc. But the discipline, strength and liveliness in dealing with the crisis, that all of you have shown up is unique’’.

He further added, Rs Rs today Chhattisgarh has set an example before the whole country for effectively controlling the corona virus epidemic, the root being sense of sacrifice and dedication in all of you towards your family and people of the state. I thank you wholeheartedly for all this. I will always be indebted to you for this cooperation. I would like to thank all the Doctors, Health workers, District and Police Administration, Food, Women and Child Development, all the employees of Municipal Corporations, Municipalities, Public Relations Department, who worked 24 hours to deal with this crisis. I will also be grateful to our friends in media, voluntary and social organizations who supported us every moment’’.

Chief Minister said that in keeping the corona crisis under control in our state, our villages have played a very important role.

Rs Rs Chhattisgarh is the state of villages and the way our villagers voluntarily followed physical distancing and cleanliness in our villages is unique. I express my gratitude with folded hands. You will be happy to know that today Chhattisgarh is being praised all over the country. Reserve Bank of India has praised us. We are at the forefront of all states in corona virus control,’’.

Baghel urged people to take complete care in daily activities. He said, Rs Rs you all should be aware of rumours. We have controlled the corona in the state, but the danger has not yet averted. We cannot give another opportunity for spread of Corona in our state. If you all follow physical distancing, wash your hands continuously and avoid creating congestion in places, there will be no chance for Corona to spread again in the State’’.

Title: IN BRIEF
Article:
Hry DGP expresses gratitude to police force

Chandigarh: Haryana Director General of Police Manoj Yadava thanked the police officers and jawans working round the clock in fighting Covid-19 and added that serving the people in the given situation has been possible with their immense support and cooperation. At the same time, he also advised them to discharge duty with utmost safety. He advised the police officers and jawans to use face masks, gloves and PPE kits, if required, to protect themselves against the risk of corona virus infection. In addition to following the social distancing norms, there is a need to be taken care of self-hygiene, food and self-protection while being on duty, he added.

UT constable suspended for violating norms

Chandigarh: The UT Police has suspended constable Mukesh Kumar, posted at PCR duty and initiated departmental inquiry against him. A spokesperson said, “A case under Section 188 and 269 IPC, was registered against Chandigarh Police constable Mukesh Kumar at Police Station-Kandaghat, district-Solan, Himachal Pradesh on the allegation that he along with one woman was moving around without any pass or permission during lockdown imposed in the state due to Covid-19 pandemic. The act of constable Mukesh Kumar was found to be grave misconduct and dereliction of duty, being a member of discipline force. He has been placed under suspension and a regular departmental enquiry has been initiated against him, the spokesman added.

Nirankari Mission contributes Rs 50L to RFs

Chandigarh: Extending a helping hand to Punjab Government for its concerted efforts against coronavirus and mitigating hardships being faced by poor and needy, the Sant Nirankari Mission has donated Rs 50 lakh in the CM Relief Fund Covid-19. Appreciating, Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh on Sunday said that this contribution would go a long way in providing succor to the needy and poor in these difficult times amid Covid-19. He also expressed gratitude to the Mission for its wholehearted support and cooperation in Government’s relentless battle against coronavirus.

BJP donates sanitiser bottles to Chd Police

Chandigarh: In a gesture of its own kind, BJP’s Chandigarh unit on Sunday handed over 7000 bottles of sanitizer to the Chandigarh Police. As many 6,700 cops are fighting against Covid-19 on ground in the police stations, PCRs and headquarters. Chandigarh’s BJP president Arun Sood formally handed over the consignment to UT DGP Sanjay Beniwal in the presence of top police officials and party workers. “We respect Covid fighters, hence this gesture. We will very soon equip sanitation workers of Municipal Corporation and door to door garbage collectors with sanitizers,” said Sood.

Humsafar doorstep service launched in Hry

Chandigarh: 'Humsafar', a mobile application based diesel at doorstep service for bulk and stationed equipment users is launched in Haryana. 'Humsafar' designed to deliver diesel anytime at doorstep will provide its fuel delivery services to farmers, farm equipment, housing societies, hotels, hospitals, malls, construction sites, industries ,banquets and other bulk buyers of diesel in various cities including Panipat, Karnal, Sonepat, Hisar, Ambala, Rohtak, Bahadurgarh, Faridabad, Rewari and Gurugram, said Sanya Goel, Director and founder of Humsafar.

516 vendors screened to check virus spread

Chandigarh: The UT Police on Sunday got screening of 516 vendors done in a move to check the spread of Coronavirus (Covid-19). In compliance with the orders and keeping in view the safety of newspaper vendors, who distribute the newspapers door to door, the Chandigarh Police did screening of total 516 vendors done with the help of a team of UT Health Department. During screening no suspect has been found, a spokesman said. Screening was done to ensure the safety of vendors as well as the residents of the sectors where vendors visit every day, he added.

Title: Fear and Anxiety to hit Indians after lockdown: Experts
Article:
Amid the nationwide lockdown due to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, health experts have warned that fear and anxiety will be more prevalent post-lockdown and people should be mentally prepared and remain positive to tackle the situation.

According to Shanu Shrivastava, psychologist at the Indian Spinal Injuries Centre in New Delhi, it is because psychologically people took time to adapt isolation and it will be again a relearning to adapt to be a social person.

"It will be certainly difficult and new experience once again as the lockdown was a new experience...person will be feeling anxious and suspicious in meeting with people as fear of coronavirus has affected our psyche," Shrivastava told IANS.

Social gatherings and handshakes will be difficult for people, celebrating festivals, and meeting people will not be easy for anyone, the doctor said.

Samir Parikh - Director of Mental Health and Behavioural Sciences, Fortis Healthcare, New Delhi said that during the lockdown, the key has been to stay positive, support one another, and stay connected with friends and family. A lot of people have also been involved with work at home.

"Once the lockdown ends, we must continue to follow all guidelines as we resume working. It's important to continue to have the same focus and continue to utilise our social connect to keep motivated. It's time to bring all our positivity and effort so we can collectively take the necessary steps for our organisation and society," Parikh told IANS.

For people to remain mentally fit, it would be important for people to maintain similar routines to the way they had been before the lockdown, the doctor suggested.

"Doing so would not only keep them more productive during the lockdown but also help transition back to work once things resume. Remember it's ok to take a couple of days to adjust, but it's best to stay mentally prepared, keep yourself updated and make a plan for how to take things ahead," he said.

Parikh also added: "We must continue to follow all guidelines as we resume working. It's important to continue to have the same focus and look forward to reconnecting with colleagues to keep motivated. It's time to bring all our positivity and effort so we can collectively take the necessary steps for our organisation and society."

According to Preeti Singh, Clinical Psychologist, Paras Hospital in Gurugram, once the lockdown opens it surely doesn't take away the uncertainty of the minds.

"We are already anxious now we all may feel exposed, more anxious of the fear of being infected, working will be out of comfort zone for a lot of us. What may hit us harder when the corporates and the employers will actually be making life-changing decisions in terms of financially, cut off in salaries, layoffs because things won't come back to what we left a few months back," she said.

"The economic burden will hit a lot of us which will also create a sense of helplessness and hopeless, sleep disturbances may be both sleep deficit or sleeping excessively, increased consumption of alcohol and smoking, in quite a few it may be leading to depressive symptoms, Singh told IANS.

One very important mantra is keeping someone closer in the loop about what we are feeling and thinking, a vent out is important, she added.

On Sunday, coronavirus cases in India have reached 15,707 including foreign nationals, with 12,969 active cases, the Union Health Ministry said in a morning update.

"A total of 2,230 patients have been cured and discharged, while the death toll stood at 507," the Ministry said.

Title: Political parties, unions condemn UT police misbehavior with journalist
Article:
Political parties, including the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD), Aam Aadmi Party (AAP), SAD Taksali, besides various media unions on Sunday strongly condemned the incident involvingmisbehaviour against senior journalist Devinderpal by Chandigarh Police while he was on his way to his office for official duty.

At the same time, SAD president Sukhbir Badal also asked the Chandigarh Administration to look into the law and order situation following wayling of another senior journalist Gurupdesh Singh Bhullar by miscreants.

“It is unfortunate that frontline warriors against deadly virus were being targeted by the police force. Media persons are playing a crucial role in making people aware about Covid-19 and even assisting the government in this task. Detaining a journalist who has stepped out during curfew is condemnable and stern disciplinary action should be taken against the erring officials,” he demanded.

AAP’s Punjab unit president Bhagwant Mann, Leader of Opposition (LoP) Harpal Singh Cheema, MLAs — Kultar Singh Sandhwan and Aman Arora also slammed the Chandigarh police for misbehaving with the journalist on Saturday evening saying that the police personnel’s behaviour was uncalled for, while demanding that Punjab Government should take up matter with Chandigarh Administration for award of punishment to the guilty policemen.

AAP also sought special financial relief or packages for journalists performing their duties in the toughest of times risking their own lives, besides demanding an insurance cover of Rs one crore for journalists performing their duties against all odd.

Meanwhile, Chandigarh Press Club (CPC), Chandigarh-Punjab Union of Journalists (CPUJ), Digital Media Association, besides other associations have also condemned Chandigarh Police for unlawful detaining of the journalist.

“CPC is taking up matter with UT Administrator VPS Badnore so that guilty official could be brought to the book and directions be issued so that no such incidence to take place in future,” said CPC secretary general Saurabh Duggal.

CHANDIGARH POLICE INITIATES INQUIRY

After complaints of harassment and demands raised from various quarters, Chandigarh Police on Sunday said it has initiated an inquiry against the police officials concerned.

"Chandigarh Police respect the fourth pillar of the democracy and considers media completely helpful fighting against the outbreak of Covid-19. At this time of crisis all over the world it is also felt that media is playing an important role in society," the police said in a statement.

It said that keeping in view Saturday's incident in which senior journalist belonging to The Tribune Group alleged facing harassment, an inquiry has been initiated against the officials concerned. The inquiry has been marked to Ombir Singh Bishnoi, DIG, UT, Chandigarh to go into details of the incident to dig out the facts behind the incident, the statement said.

Title: Drizzle, hailtstorm likely to hit state today
Article:
Drizzle accompanied by strong wind and hailstorm is predicted in some of places across the state on Monday. Meanwhile, capital’s Raipur city weather turned pleasant on Sunday as the mercury dropped a few notches after it had soared high for the last couple of days. Meteorologists described it a reason of humidity coming in from Bay of Bengal through the southern part. Dr HP Chandra, weather scientist at the regional centre of the Indian Meteorological Centre, said the reason behind the turnaround in weather was due to a trough generated towards northern Chhattisgarh at south eastern part of Madhya Pradesh.

Humidity is also coming in from Bay of Bengal which has turned the weather in most of the parts of state pleasant, he said.

Rs Rs Because of its effect, light showers are expected in one or two places in almost entire state,’’ he said, adding lightning could also be observed accompanied by light showers.

Title: More than one lakh metric tonnes mustard procured in Hry
Article:
During the ongoing procurement season, Haryana Government has procured more than one lakh metric tonnes of mustard from the farmers in the state.

Haryana Additional Chief Secretary Agriculture and Farmers’ Welfare and Cooperation Department Sanjeev Kaushal said that 6,030 farmers reported at the 163 procurement centres for procurement of mustard in the state on Sunday.

A total of about 16,152.68 metric tonnes of mustard was purchased by the procurement agencies, i.e., HAFED and State Warehousing Corporation from these farmers.

A total of 1,00,033.22 metric tonnes has been procured from 38,399 farmers in the state in the first five days of procurement. 137 farmers have voluntarily contributed a sum of Rs 1,63,267 to the Haryana Corona Relief Fund, he said.

Kaushal informed that wheat procurement will commence tomorrow in more than 1,800 procurement centres all over the states.

More than 12,600 employees of the Procurement Agencies, HAFED, HWC, FCI and Food and Supplies Department have been deployed in these procurement centres. Masks, thermal scanners and sanitizers will be utilized for protection of the farmers and social distancing will be ensured, he said.

In a major relaxation of the existing guidelines, he said that all conditions of the quantity restrictions for the wheat produce brought to mandi by the farmer have been waived off.

Title: Three fresh cases reported in Chd, total tally stands at 26
Article:
Three fresh cases of Covid-19 have been reported in Chandigarh on Sunday, taking the total tally to 26.

The total number of active positive cases in Chandigarh now stands at 13.

Two more positive patients were cured and discharged from the hospital on Sunday. With this, the recovered patients are now 13 in the city.

“Three new Covid-19 positive cases have been diagnosed in Chandigarh. They are family contacts of Covid-19 positive case of Sector 30 female, who was tested positive on Friday. The fresh cases include her 56 years old husband, 25 years old son and a one-and-a-half year granddaughter,” said an official spokesman.

“Out of seven family contacts of Covid-19 positive case of 50 year old male from Dhanas, six have turned out to be negative and result of one of them is still awaited. Eight remote community contacts of the same case at Dhanas have been sampled at PGIMER,” the spokesman said.

The Dhanas resident is a sanitary attendant at PGIMER and was tested positive for Covid-19 on Friday.

Till the filing of this story, the report of 15 tests was still awaited till Sunday evening.

The spokesman further said that two more Covid-19 patients who have been treated and cured have been discharged from PGIMER. They included 23 years old male resident of Sector 29, who was contact of Sector 30 Dubai returned resident. Other recovered patient is 32 years old male NRI from Canada living in Sector 33 here.

A total of 430 samples have been tested so far while 388 have tested negative. As a precautionary measure, 1961 people have been put in home quarantine, out of which 1391 have completed the quarantine period in the city.

Notably, the first positive case of Covid-19 was reported on March 19 in the city. A curfew was imposed in Chandigarh from March 24 onwards to ensure social distancing and contain the spread of Covid-19.

Title: Ailing elephant calf’s sample sent for COVID-19 test
Article:
Following the guidelines of the Central Government, Rajaji National Park has sent samples of an elephant calf to Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI) Bareilly to check for COVID-19. According to the Rajaji director Amit Verma, one of the trained elephants in Rajaji was suffering for about a month from elephant pox. However, considering the COVID-19 pandemic, the pachyderm’s sample has been sent to IVRI for tests as a precautionary measure. The samples of a leopard found dead some days ago have also been sent to the institute to check for COVID-19.

It will be recalled that after a tiger in a New York zoo had tested positive for COVID-19 earlier this month, the Ministry of Environment and Forests had issued advisory to all states regarding the monitoring of wild animals in zoos and protected areas for any abnormal behaviour or symptoms of the disease. The sample report of the elephant is expected on Monday.

Title: Maharaj requests Union MoS to send stranded Nepalis back home
Article:
The State’s Tourism and Irrigation Minister Satpal Maharaj has requested the Union Minister of State for Home Affairs, Nityanand Rai to facilitate the return of 1,500 Nepali citizens stranded in Uttarakhand to the Nepal.

Maharaj stated that he had informed the union minister of state that due to the lockdown, about 1,500 Nepali citizens had been stranded in and around Dharchula in the border district of Pithoragarh. These Nepalis have been stranded in Uttarakhand for quite some time.

Efforts were also made to facilitate their entry into Nepal but the Nepalese government refused to grant entry to its citizens.

Maharaj said that he had requested the Union minister of State for Home Affairs that arrangements should be made to send the stranded Nepalis back to their nation before or after the lifting of the lockdown.

Failing this, there could be possibility of increase risk of contagion in the border area of Uttarakhand.

It is worth mentioning here that a number of Nepalis migrate to Uttarakhand to work as daily wagers and labourers in different sectors. The local administration is currently taking care of the basic requirements of the stranded Nepalis in Pithoragarh district.

Title: People can approach MCD through district control room number
Article:
The locals of Dehradun can complain to or request necessary assistance from the Municipal Corporation of Dehradun (MCD) through the control room number issued by district administration—0135- 2726066- as the corporation's helpline number is not working. People have been complaining for weeks that the helpline number of MCD is not working due to which several locals are unable to complain about various issues in their area during the lockdown. "We wanted to complain about the sanitation workers in our area who just pile up the garbage near the colony and do not pick it up for many days. I tried to call the helpline number and others mentioned on the corporation's site but I got no response from there, " said Shanti Vihar resident Sunita Vishwakarma.

Talking about it, deputy municipal commissioner Rohitash Sharma said that after the lockdown was announced due to novel Coronavirus (COVID-19), the MCD's helpline number was closed. He further informed that the corporation is getting the complaints through the control room number issued by district administration. "We get the requests and complaints about cleaning or sanitation through the district control room number. All the complaints received for municipal corporation are sent to us," said Sharma. He added that people can contact the control room number of district administration for their queries or complaints regarding the corporation.

Title: SCPCR to issue advisory to State Govt on school fees
Article:
The State Commission for Protection of Child Rights (SCPCR) will issue an advisory to the Uttarakhand Government about the private schools purportedly pressurising parents to submit the school fees of their children during the lockdown. Several parents have complained to SCPCR about the schools pressurising them to pay the school fees including the charges for the facilities which are not even being utilised by students.

Even before the implementation of lockdown, various schools were already not operating due to concerns caused by novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) spread. Though many of the schools are reportedly facilitating online classes, they are also continuously pressurising parents to deposit the school fees including various other charges.

"My two children study in seventh standard. Last week, the school mailed us asking us to deposit three months fee that included transportation charges, lab charges, sports fees and others. The school is hardly providing a one hour online class per day since the lockdown implementation. It is totally unfair to demand such a hefty amount just for one hour online class," said Haldwani resident Sandhya Dwivedy. According to Rajpur resident Harish Bhandari, “I am quite furious that our state government has not issued any strict orders to stop such harassment by school administration.

We are getting the reminders from school to deposit the fees of my three kids every day. I work in Delhi but since the implementation of lockdown I have been here and without any pay I cannot deposit three months fee that include all the unnecessary charges.”

On this issue, the chairperson of SCPCR Usha Negi opined that when everyone in the country is trying to help others in every possible way, some schools are still thinking about making money.

She said that those schools that run under charitable trusts and societies are also pressurising parents for fee submission when there is actually an opportunity to do some help and charity. However, there are some schools which have waived off three month fee considering the current crisis, informed Negi. The SCPCR will issue an advisory to the State Government and the Education Department about schools pressurising parents for fee submission, said Negi. She added that no school would be allowed to hike fees even after the lockdown, or charge for any other facilities which are not currently being used by students.

Reportedly, the Principals Progressive Schools’ Association (PPSA) had earlier questioned how the schools would pay salaries to staff if the school fee of three months is waived off. Talking about this, Negi said that paying the staff does not mean that schools will ask for unnecessary charges during the crisis. On being asked about the said issue, chief education officer Asha Rani Painuly stated that until the state administration gives any instructions, nothing can be done by her on this matter.

Title: Prevention is the key
Article:
In the last couple of decades global warming and consequential ecological problems have been at the centre stage of all climate change discourse. Even if in varying degrees, all developed and developing nations are bearing the impact of globally rising decadal temperatures. Due to the increasing anomalies in weather cycles globally, nations are negotiating possibilities of maximum reduction in green house gas emissions.

A higher concentration of green house gases in the atmosphere has been linked to melting of glaciers, recurrent flooding, droughts, forest fires and resulting population displacement. However there is an important yet often neglected aspect of this global climate crisis. Thus is the prospect of new and deadlier epidemics which have been emanating in the last few years. A greater threat is that such challenging infectious diseases could only proliferate in complexity and number in the coming years. The two most critical areas which can have a potential impact on human health in contemporary world are - climate change and solid waste management. Both are also intricately linked to one another.

The pandemic of Covid- 19 which the world is currently confronting, is a grim instance of how a rapidly contaminating ecosystem is more susceptible to unprecedented human health problems.

It becomes indispensable therefore that all health risks associated with faulty waste management are eliminated. The present crisis is only a warning to the many more epidemics which can arise due to lacunae in effective waste disposal mechanisms.

At the same time it is also a reminder of the need to build better resilience in the face of such natural disasters should they recur in the future.

Most Asian counties including India are experiencing a demographic trend, where population is becoming rapidly urbanised.

In fact half of the world’s mega cities are presently found in Asia. With a haphazard and rapid urban growth, a plethora of infrastructural -economic problems have come up too. The highly industrialised cities despite being engines of economic growth have also become massive generators of solid waste.

The very relationship between solid waste and climatic problems lays in the faulty and non systematic manner in which the former is dealt with. Most of the urbanised metropolitans in India are seething under this vicious cycle of waste mismanagement and environmental degradation. Only a partial chunk of the total urban waste being generated is collected by the municipal authorities and even this waste is dumped in dump sites and landfills.

In fact the waste sector is an identifiable contributor to the total green house gas emissions in India. The emissions in municipal solid waste sector can be attributed to the burning of waste and decaying in the dumping sites. Such activities lead to the emitting of carbon di oxide as well as methane. The sudden rise in many lung disorders in India in past few years can be attributed to crippling levels of particulate matter pollution in India.

Leachate percolation from landfills into the ground water is also a major source of pollution. The metal residues present in leachate enter the food chain as ground water is often used for drinking and irrigation purposes.

This poses a serious public health hazard. The landfills have also been reported to be a breeding ground for disease hosting organisms. Thus a clean and better organised waste management system has to be implemented with cooperation from various sections in the community. At individual level proper segregation as well as minimisation of waste are practices which can go a long run in reducing the menace. A critical aspect of disease prevention during the present crisis is ensuring the safety of waste collecting personnel.

Despite all preventive measures being implemented by the Government, the threat of further spread of the Covid-19 disease cannot be completely ruled out.

As communities are practicing social distancing and observing the lockdown regulations, the dependence on few essential services is indispensable. Facilities like municipal waste collection have to be carried out compulsorily for the upkeep and hygiene maintenance of the community.

As the waste collection personnel are risking their lives in disposing their duties, it also becomes the duty of all the citizens to facilitate their work by extending utmost cooperation. Any careless disposal of medical waste can be a potential source of COVID-19 infection to the municipal workers and rag-pickers.

People must be educated to dispose off their gloves, tissues, sanitiser bottles and used masks into separate bags. Besides, people must also segregate their household waste into different categories like - organic, dry and bio medical waste.

Such a segregation of waste at source will automatically reduce the need for municipal workers to touch and separate waste manually, thereby ensuring their safety further.

Thus by making informed choices and by ensuring our cooperation to the Government we can prevent the dreaded Covid-19 from spreading its wings further.

Climate change and mismanaged waste are the most tangible caused of communicable diseases. So real resistance and resilience can be achieved by an overhauling of our waste management systems and mitigating other major causes of ecological pollution.

As we fight the Covid-19 pandemic, hoping to recover from its clutches soon, we must be futuristic by learning to treat our ecology with care and respect which it deserves.

(The author is a retired civil servant)

Title: Property registration to start with conditions in Hry
Article:
To facilitate the general public during lockdown period, Haryana Government has issued consolidated revised guidelines, to carry out the delivery of public services namely Registration of Instruments under Sections 17 and 18 of the Registration Act, 1908 amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

“The State Government has decided to limit number of deeds to be registered in a tehsil or sub-tehsil to 24 per working day with a gap of five minutes each so as to maintain social distancing and to avoid over-crowding,” said an official spokesman.

He said that in the State, registration of instruments pertaining to transfer of property and delivery of copies of revenue records, registration deeds, entries and attestation of mutations, attestation of affidavits and issuance of various kinds of certificates, such as Scheduled Caste Certificates, Backward Class/OBC Certificates, issuance of Residence Certificates, Domicile Certificates, and Income Certificates etc will start from April 20.

He informed that since tehsildars (sub registrars) and naib tehsildars (joint sub registrars) are also engaged in disaster management related duties, it has been decided that all these work would be carried out from 4 pm to 5 pm on all working days. Similarly, registration of sale deeds etc. will be undertaken during 2 pm to 4 pm only on working days.

The spokesman further said that for the purpose of identification, there is no requirement of any lambardar or advocate to identify the executants or in whose favour the sale deeds are being executed as witnesses if they have aadhar cards or any other government issued photo identity cards. This will also be applicable in case of attestation of affidavits and Caste certificates etc.

To maintain social distancing and to avoid overcrowding in tehsils or sub-tehsils, the applicants will come after seeking prior on-line appointments. The online appointments will also serve as a pass for movement from their residence to the concerned tehsil or sub tehsil. Online appointment can be taken only either by the seller or transferor or the GPA/SPA, as the case may be, or by the vendee(s)/transferee(s) in whose favour the deed is being executed.

If after completion of 14 days of quarantine or isolation period of affected person (s) in a containment zone, if a cluster is taken out of containment zone the revised guidelines will be applicable and these activities may be carried out therein accordingly, the spokesman said.

All the Deputy Commissioners will ensure that this work is carried out strictly as per Union Ministry of Home Affairs and Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare’s guidelines relating to Covid-19 and lockdown and there is no violation of conditions of social distancing, he added.

Title: PGIMER selected to provide training on Covid-19 to SAARC health professionals
Article:
The region’s tertiary healthcare institute—Post Graduate Institute of Medical Education and Research will conduct an online 10-day capacity building program on Covid-19 (coronavirus) for SAARC health professionals to deal with the pandemic.

The program will disseminate the best and replicable practices along with experiences of India to contain Covid-19 pandemic as a follow-up of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s initiated video conference of SAARC leaders on March 15, where he suggested that healthcare professionals of the SAARC nations could come together to jointly fight the coronavirus pandemic.

The program will be organized by Department of Community Medicine & School of Public Health, PGIMER. The Union Ministry of External Affairs has selected the PGIMER for conducting this online capacity building program, said an official spokesperson.

The senior healthcare professionals from countries namely Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Maldives, Mauritius, Nepal, Seychelles and Sri Lanka will participate in the program.

PGIMER Prof. Jagat Ram appreciated and underscored the importance of this flagship program in this current challenging situation where all countries across the globe are struggling to find the solutions to address Covid-19 pandemic.

He reiterated that the program spearheaded by Dr. Sonu Goel, Professor in Department of Community Medicine and School of Public Health will help SAARC countries to effectively plan and manage coronavirus situation in their respective countries.

The online programme will be delivered by experts from Chandigarh Administration and eminent faculty of Institute on various important topics like understanding Covid, infection prevention measures, diagnosis and clinical management of Covid patients and their contacts, field surveillance and public health measures and other emergency issues. During the program, health workers will be motivated by Ted ex speaker Vivek Atray (former IAS officer) and yoga practice will be stressed upon in tackling mental stress in this tough situation, the spokesperson said.

In total, there will be 10 modules (each of one hour) and each module shall have 4-5 lectures and entire program will be completed in 10 days, the spokesperson added.

A short documentary film featuring key messages of international managers and leaders from across 40 countries will also be displayed during the program.

Key speakers would include Manoj Kumar Parida, Advisor to the Administrator, MCC Commissioner KK Yadav, SSP Nilambari Jagadale among others.

Title: Down the memory lane… #MeAt20
Article:
The latest nostalgic social media tread is posting pictures of yourself at age 20. The trend appears to have sparked by a tweeter user, who tweeted a simple prompt a couple of days ago.

Soon, the trend also became popular in social media platforms Facebook as well as twitter and celebrities from Bollywood to Hollywood thereafter took part in it with people intermittently tagging their photos with #MeAt20, #20yearsold, and #Age20.

The trend became popular in Chhattisgarh too and a series of tweets of political leaders and senior bureaucrats as well started pouring in.

Two of the bigwigs in Chhattisgarh politics, Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel and Health Minister T.S. Singhdeo also took part in it by posting photograph in their twitter handle of their decades old photographs.

Photo trends like this on Twitter aren't uncommon, and the trend's popularity isn't much of a surprise given the degree to which people are turning to social media for attention while maintaining social distancing.

Title: 18 fresh cases push Haryana tally to 250
Article:
With 18 fresh cases, Haryana’s Covid-19 tally jumped to 250 on Sunday.

Nine new positive cases were reported from Faridabad, four each from Gurugram and Ambala and one from Bhiwani.

“The coronavirus count rose to 250 in Haryana with 18 more people, including a jail warder and a health worker, testing positive for the infection on Sunday,” according to the state Health Department’s evening bulletin.

The jail warden posted in Gurugram’s Bhondsi jail tested positive for the infection after he returned from leave. The warden was on leave since April 9 and had visited his hometown in Bhiwani. He was tested for the infection when he showed its symptoms on joining duty.

An auxiliary nurse midwife (ANM) who worked in a containment zone in Ambala was also tested positive for the infection.

Ambala chief medical officer Dr Kuldeep Singh said the other three patients from the district were members of a family which lived at Sahjadpur village near Ambala City.

He said they were taking treatment from a Panchkula doctor, who had earlier failed to inform the authorities about a coronavirus positive woman, whose eight members of family also tested positive for the disease a few days ago.

The Ambala authorities have collected the list of all those who had got themselves treated from the doctor.

According to the state’s health bulletin, the total active Covid-19 patients in the State are 144 while 104 patients have been cured and discharged from hospitals.

The state has so far recorded two coronavirus deaths.

The worst-affected districts of the State with the maximum number of positive cases are Nuh with 57 cases, Faridabad with 42 cases, Gurugram with 36 cases and Palwal with 34.

As many as 12,687 samples have been tested so far, of which 10,230 have tested negative. However, the report of 2,221 samples is awaited.

The total number of cases includes 24 foreign nationals, of which 14 were the Italian tourists. Thirteen of them were discharged while one elderly woman in the group had passed away recently even though she had recovered from the infection.

The other 10 foreign nationals found infected with the virus are from countries Sri Lanka, Nepal, Thailand, South Africa and Indonesia while 64 are from other states, the bulletin stated.

Meanwhile, Health Minister Anil Vij said 19,663 teams have been constituted for the door-to-door screening of people.

“If anyone shows Covid-19 symptoms like fever, cough, cold, their samples will be taken,” he said.

To stop the spread of Covid-19, containment orders have already been issued by concerned District Magistrates or Deputy Commissioners in 39 villages or colonies in Nuh, 17 villages in Palwal, 8 villages in Sonepat, 5 villages in Karnal, 13 villages in Faridabad, 2 villages in Bhiwani, 4 villages in Charkhi Dadri, 18 villages in Gurugram, 1 village in Jind, 2 villages in Fatehabad, 1 village in Panipat, 1 village in Kaithal, 1 village in Jhajjar, 3 villages in Panchkula, 2 villages in Sirsa, 1 village in Hisar, 19 villages in Ambala, 2 villages in Yamuna Nagar and 1 Sector in Kurukshetra.

Title: Hry decides to re-employ retired Govt doctors to deal with Covid-19 pandemic
Article:
Keeping in view the Covid-19 pandemic situation in the State, Haryana Government has decided to re-employ the retired Government doctors below the age of 69 years on contractual basis for one year against vacant posts.

The Chief Minister Manohar Lal has approved a proposal in this regard, said a spokesman of Haryana Health Department. He said that the maximum age for applying has been fixed as 69 years so that the doctors could serve the Department upto 70 years. The respective Civil Surgeons will be authorized to engage these doctors at their level, he added.

Giving details about filling up the vacant posts in various medical institutes, the spokesman said that the State Government has granted permission to the Directors of Government Medical Colleges namely Kalpana Chawla Government Medical College Karnal, BPS Government Medical College, Khanpur Kalan, Sonipat and Shaheed Hasan Khan Mewati, Government Medical College, Nalhar, Nuh to fill up 197 vacant posts of faculty on contractual basis from the retired doctors upto the age of 70 years for one year or till the regular incumbent joins, whichever is earlier for the effective management of Covid-19 pandemic in the state.

While 13 posts of Professor, 29 posts of Associate Professor and 54 posts of Assistant Professor would be filled up in Kalpana Chawla Government Medical College Karnal, 8 posts of Professor Super Speciality, 7 posts of Associate Professor Super Speciality, 8 posts of Assistant Professor Super Speciality, 9 posts of Professor Speciality, 15 posts of Associate Professor Speciality and 10 posts of Assistant Professor Speciality would be filled up in BPS Government Medical College, Khanpur Kalan, Sonipat. Apart from this, 10 posts of Professor, 19 posts of Associate Professor and 15 posts of Assistant Professor would be filled up in Shaheed Hasan Khan Mewati, Government Medical College, Nalhar, Nuh, the spokesman said.

Title: Punjab cops over 55 yrs or with pre-existing medical risk not be deployed on Covid duty
Article:
A day after Ludhiana Assistant Commissioner of Police (ACP) died of coronavirus, Punjab Director General of Police (DGP) Dinkar Gupta on Sunday ordered non-deployment of cops over 55 years or those with pre-existing medical risk on frontline jobs.

Announcing several protective and welfare measures for the police personnel on

Covid-19 duty, DGP also ordered strict compliance of his orders on weekly off or rest days of all policemen on frontline duties.

The State police chief had directed all the Commissioners of Police and Senior Superintendents of Police to follow a rotational system of providing a weekly off or rest to the frontline personnel, with efforts to organize deployment in such a manner that two days of rest can be provided to all personnel after every 10 days.

He has also directed that police personnel over 55 years of age or those with pre-existing and enhanced medical risk factors, such as hypertension issues, cardiac history, asthma or a compromised or suppressed immune system for any reason, should not be deployed on the frontline, as far as possible.

To ensure protection for these police personnel, the DGP has also requested the state Chief Secretary Karan Avtar Singh to direct the State Health Department to provide a minimum of 4050 PPE kits or suits and 18,000 N-95 masks on immediate basis.

“At present, some PPE suits are already available with the Police department, which are being used during the performance of sensitive tasks.

However, the police officers deployed at hotspots, containment zones, clusters, isolation wards, Covid hospitals (Levels 1-2-3) need PPE suits, which are certified by the Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare,” he said.

Gupta said that the police personnel who have to come in close contact with either confirmed or suspect cases of coronavirus, while carrying out debriefing, contact tracing and tracking of Tablighi Jamaat cases etc also need such PPE kits.

Listing the welfare measures for police personnel discharging their duties amid Covid-19, the DGP said that to boost their immunity, about 1.36 lakh tablets of multi-vitamins have been distributed among the cops. The police personnel are also being provided with nutritious, rich and adequate diet, to minimize risk to those exposed to coronavirus, and also facing the threat of lowered immunity due to lack of sleep and rest.

Notably, between 43,000 to 48,000 Punjab Police personnel have been deployed in various districts of the state on different days to enforce the curfew in the State, ensure distribution of food, essential supplies and medicines, besides operating Dial 112 Helplines and Covid Helplines etc.

Title: Sidhu defies CM’s order to wear masks at public places
Article:
Cricketer-turned-politician Navjot Singh Sidhu’s ‘mask-less’ act of distributing masks has come under Amritsar Administration’s scanner with the Chief Minister’s Office forwarding a demand notice against the Congress MLA to the Deputy Commissioner concerned. The development comes after a Chandigarh-based advocate has written a letter to the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh demanding to put Sidhu into home quarantine and also withdraw his security during the lockdown period as the former minister is roaming around in Amritsar without a mask amid Covid-19 scare.

Advocate and activist HC Arora, in his letter, has also set a three-day deadline for the Chief Minister, while making it clear that he would be “left with no other option, except to file an urgent writ petition (PIL) in the High Court, for seeking requisite relief, in the public interest”.

“Needless to state that in case appropriate action is not taken on this demand within next two or three days, in that event, I shall be left with no other option, except to file an urgent writ petition (PIL) in the Hon’ble High Court, for seeking requisite relief, in the public interest,” said Arora, in his letter to the Chief Minister.

It has been learnt that the Chief Minister, after receiving the demand notice through e-mail, has forwarded the same to Amritsar Deputy Commissioner for taking appropriate action.

Notably, Arora has also written to the Chief Minister on April 17 urging him to direct the authorities at Amritsar to register an FIR against “VIP figure” for repeatedly moving in the city without wearing a face mask, and thereby putting not only his safety but also the safety of the public, at risk due to spread of Covid-19 pandemic.

The same day, Arora noted, the Chief Minister had issued strict instructions to authorities all over Punjab to challan all those people who come outside their homes without wearing face masks. “I have, however, to point out that ink on your orders had not even dried when yesterday again Sidhu travelled on Amritsar roads in his car, and then came out of his car in front of Civil Hospital, Amritsar, without any mask on his face,” he said while pointing at the related news telecasted on national TV news channels.

Arora added, “Thus, a stage has been reached when Sidhu should be restrained from coming out of his residence and should be ordered to be put under home quarantine during the whole of curfew period, and his security should also be withdrawn, or to register a case against him, as he is misusing his security also by taking his security men along while violating the curfew order,” he demanded. Action be also initiated against Amritsar DC or Commissioner “for deliberate inaction in this sensitive matter pertaining to the safety of the public”. Sidhu, on Saturday, donated 1,000 N95 masks to frontline healthcare personnel of Amritsar and Taran Tarn civil hospitals, and the Government Medical College in Amritsar — which was his fifth public visit since the curfew was imposed in Punjab. To top it all! He defied government orders of mandatory wearing of masks in all his visits. During his brief visits across his constituency, even his security guards and supporters were not seen wearing masks.

It may be pointed that Punjab has made wearing a mask compulsory in public past week. On Friday, the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh had ordered strict enforcement of the compulsory wearing of masks in the public and asked the police to take stringent action, including the imposition of fines, against the violators.

SIDHU’s DEFENCE

In his defence, Sidhu’s office released a statement, saying, “WHO stresses that it is critical that medical masks and respirators be prioritized for healthcare workers and reminds that a mask should only be used by health workers, care takers, and individuals with respiratory symptoms, such as fever and cough.

Thus, WHO advises rational use of medical masks to avoid unnecessary wastage of precious resources and misuse of masks. There is a world-wide shortage of masks, so WHO urges people to use masks wisely.” “The WHO recommends to only wear a mask if you are ill with Covid-19 symptoms (especially coughing) or looking after someone who may have Covid-19. Disposable face mask can only be used once. If you are not ill or (not) looking after someone who is ill then you are wasting a mask,” the statement, released on Saturday, added.

Title: Measures taken to save wildlife in Zoo: Hry Chief warden
Article:
Stating that the Wildlife wing of Haryana Forest department has taken all preventive measures to protect the animals from the deadly corona Virus by keeping a close watch on them, Alok Verma, PCCF and chief warden, Haryana said those staff involved in dealing with animals and birds in Zoos being kept on highest alert.

“Adequate measures such as entire Zoos being frequently sanitised, only essential staff allowed to work, strict social distancing, and keepers maintaining minimum contact with animals, among others are being taken to ensure the welfare of animals,” Verma said, adding that all arrangements have been made as per NTCA guidelines. The National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) and the Central Zoo Authority had earlier issued directions regarding the same. In Haryana, there are four Zoos at Rohtak, Bhiwani, Hisar and Pipli (Kurukshetra) and Bird Sanctuaries in Bhindawas (Jhajjar), Sultanpur (Gurugram) and a National Park in Kalesar, Yamunanagar.

The Chief Warden said that elaborate measures have been taken to protect the health of captive animals and birds in Zoos in view of this epidemic. Additional bio-security measures, including daily health screening of staff, had been introduced, he said, adding the patrolling staffs have also been asked to keep an eye on any abnormal behaviour by the wildlife at their jurisdictional limit. In addition to this, instructions were given to minimise human-animal interactions, use of safety gear by the staff, isolation of sick animals and sending their samples for testing to three identified veterinary labs.

Yamuna Nagar DFO (Wildlife) Shiv Singh said that the staff have been asked to stay put at the posts and they are being supplied with essentials there to prevent the possibility of their getting infected with COVID-19 and then passing it on to the animals that they have to handle. Zoo keepers who handle them are also being subjected to regular thermal screening to check if they have any symptoms of corona, he said, adding that the food for captive animals is sanitised at the gates before being brought in to be served to them.

“Strict guidelines have been issued to the staff to inform the authorities if they spot the carcass of an animal within the reserve or at its peripheries. They have been asked to inform the senior officers if they see signs of illness in an animal,” he said. Singh said, “The instructions were issued to observe symptoms consistent with COVID-19, such as respiratory signs of nasal discharge, coughing and laboured breathing through direct observation in animals. In case of symptoms, the animals are to be isolated and samples to be collected and sent to the designated animal health institutes to initiate COVID-19 testing, while following all biocontainment and safety measures as per the national protocol.”

The National Institute of High Security Animal Disease (NIHSAD), Bhopal, the National Research Centre on Equines (NRCE), Hisar and the Centre for Animal Disease Research and Diagnostic (CADRAD), Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI), Izatnagar, Bareilly are the designated animal health institutes named by the Central Zoo Authority for the purpose of conducting COVID-19 testing.

He said that all vehicles carrying food material are passed through a trough filled with anti-microbial solution in Zoos so that microbes attached to the tyres are removed. Instruction has been given to officials concerned to ensure availability of food and medicinal requirements of animals during lockdown. Singh said wild animals are having a gala time during the lockdown as they are getting bolder and becoming explorers as areas outside their habitat are becoming quiet.

"Wild-life is always happy when environment becomes quiet. They (wild animals) are roaming not only in their own areas but also outside in forest fringe areas," he said, adding that due to human activity and busy roads otherwise, they never used to venture out. Now, even spotted deer is trying to come out and "see what all is happening".

He further said that they (wild animals) are basically free-ranging animals; when they find that their surroundings have become quiet, they tend to come out and explore. When asked about a leopard attacking a labourer working in the fields and injured him near Pratap Nagar town of Yamunanagar district on April 15, Singh said that big cat might have gone there for hunting dogs when the incident occurred. In front of officials, leopard went to forest area on the same day.

Meanwhile, officials have been directed to keep a vigil so that wild animals such as leopard don’t enter the fields and human habitations. At the same time, as a part of precaution, harvesting should not be done till late evening in some areas, he advised.

When asked about illegal wildlife trade on the rise amid the nationwide lockdown, he said that there is no such report so far. "Patrolling has been intensified and officers are put on alert. They have been strictly directed to protect exotic birds and save them from being traded," Singh said. The Department has taken measures, including stepping up night patrolling, to curb such activities, he added.

He further said that all precautions had been taken to deal with forest fires. "Round-the-clock monitoring is being undertaken to ensure timely action in cases of detection of forest fires", Singh added.

Title: Seven more Covid-19 suspects test +ve
Article:
At least seven more cases of Covid-19 came to fore in Jharkhand on Sunday, taking the total count of coronavirus cases in State to 41, health officials said.

Confirming the seven cases, State health secretary Dr Nitin Madan Kulkarni said, "Seven new cases of Covid-19 have been reported. Five cases have been reported from Hindpiri, the epicentre of the pandemic in State. One case has been reported from Bero in Ranchi district while other case has been reported from Simdega.”

With Sunday's findings, the number of positive cases in Simdega has increased to two.

Last week a youth from Simdega was tested postive.

Sources said that the emergence of new cases in Bero and Simdega is cause of concern for State government as both the cases have been reported from rural areas.

Sources said that three cases –two in Ranchi and one in Bero—have links with Tablighi Jamaat, however the district administration is yet to give an official confirmation on this.

Ranchi SDM Lokesh Mishra said, "The administration is enquiring about the links of these persons with Jammat."

On Sunday 93 samples were tested in first slot out of which 89 cases were found to be negative, four cases were found positive.

The four cases which were found in the first half of Sunday are of varied age group. Sources said the man who tested positive in Bero is 52-year-old, Simdega youth is 17-year-old while two cases which were recovered from state capital are in age group of 24 and 42 years respectively. The remaining three were reported in late evening.

The first case of COVID-19 was reported on March 31, after a Malaysian woman was tested positive. The woman had reached Ranchi from Delhi after attending the Tablighi Jamaat ( religious convention). Since the recovery of first case in Hindpiri area where the woman was hiding, Hindpiri area has emerged as epicentre of Coronavirus.

On April 2, a positive case was reported from Vishnugarh in Hazaribag followed by cases in Bokaro and other parts of state, but the Hindpiri area still accounts for nearly sixty per cent cases in Jharkhand. Ranchi Hindpiri is hotspot with maximum 21 cases. The district wise figures are Ranchi 22, nine from Bokaro, two from Hazaribag, two from Simdega, one from Dhanbad, Giridih, Koderma.

The district administration has taken several measures to check the spread of disease in Hindpiri area. The entire area has been sealed since the recovery of cases in the area. The district administration is making door to door delivery of foodgrains and medicines. The administration has assigned the job of delivery of foodgrains to volunteers.

Title: Coronavirus suspect escapes from isolation ward in Daltonganj
Article:
n A 28-year-old man whose swabs were sent for test in RIMS Ranchi escaped from Daltonganj based isolation ward set up in Palamu medical college hospital on Saturday.

His escape was noticed the same Saturday night and since then a big hunt is on to track him down by three teams of police but he continues to be untraced till the time of filing of this report.

Civil surgeon John F Kennedy said as his swabs were sent for test report of which is yet to come. He was taken down into cornovirus isolation ward on April 17 only and slipped from there on April 18. Kennedy said his health condition was not any worrisome when he was brought in the isolation ward

Kennedy describing his escape as most unfortunate and unwarranted said a test of swab is just for ruling out any morbidity but here this youth in his sheer frustration and ignorance made his escape much to everyone right from health officials to police’s acute stress.

Sources said a repair work is on in the vicinity of this isolation ward which itself raises eyebrows as to how repair work can so go on near or close to the isolation ward as then there will be many hands there to work and there will be many footfall there too.

Sources said this repair or renovation work in the vicinity ought to have been a total avoidable thing but here at this isolation ward its going on poses too many questions to health safety measures.

Sources said the workers engaged in this repair/ renovation work are not equipped with any protective shoes and gloves except masks on their faces.

Sources said it is suspected this youth taking advantage of the presence of these labourers escaped when they after winding up their day’s work on Saturday trooped for their respective homes.

SP Palamu Ajay Linda said, “SDPO Sandip Kumar Gupta has apprised me of this work going on there. Police will look into it as to how this can be so allowed in and around isolation ward.”

Linda said he has sought a full report from SDPO in this regard. SP said there should not be movement of people not connected in any way to health duties there at any isolation ward.

Gupta said to the Pioneer,“I too do not understand the exigency of any work that is so going on there even on Sunday today. Police will delve deep into this issue.”

Gupta said, “The escapee had come to Palamu before Holi in March. He came from Gujarat. He had some fever and so villagers pressed him to be here in the isolation ward where he was admitted on April 17 but in panic and foolishness he went out from here without anyone noticing his escape.”

Gupta said, “Our SP Linda has given us this big task to find him out and we are on it but the youth continues to outsmart us.”

Title: Hry prepares plan to start operations of industries after April 20
Article:
To deal with the adverse impact on economic activities caused by Covid-19 pandemic, Haryana Government has finalized a system for starting uninterrupted operation of industries and other establishments in the state beginning from April 20.

The plan has been prepared as per consolidated revised guidelines issued by the Government of India, said an official spokesman.

He said that as per the guidelines, in the State to obtain permission to resume operations and apply for passes, the applicant shall apply on SARAL Haryana portal. Further, the passes for the interstate movement of vehicles shall be applied on government of India portal for e-pass.

The spokesman said that opening of shops or dhabas on highways and movement of self employed individuals will be strictly governed by the Ministry of Home Affairs guidelines.

He said that in view of approaching summer season and new academic session, distribution of books by book shops to school and college students and sale of Air conditioners, Air coolers, Fans and their repair shops may be treated as essential goods or services and allowed to remain open and operate outside containment zone.

However, the District Magistrates can fix the timings of various establishments, industries, and other permitted activities depending upon the local requirements, the spokesman added.

The spokesman further said that for carrying out the operations of industries and other establishments, Committees will be constituted at block level, town level and city level to scrutinize and approve application. In rural areas, a committee of SDM, DSP, BDPO and Assistant Labour Commissioner and in the urban areas a committee of SDM, DSP, EO or Secretary of Municipal Corporation and Assistant Labor Commissioner will issue the passes for industries and other establishments having up to 25 people, he said.

Title: Man arrested for spreading hate msgs
Article:
A man has been arrested in Chhattisgarh for spreading hate messages against a community on Facebook in related to the novel coronavirus crisis.

The police launched a probe against the accused after his fake FB profile of a woman was reported by few users. During the investigation, the police found that the accuused, an engineering student, was running a fake account.

The accused was running the FB account with the fake identity of a woman named Nisha Jindal, which had more than 10,000 followers. He had posted objectionable comments against a particular community associated with the spread of the deadly new virus.

The information of his arrest was posted by IAS officer Priyanka Shukla on Twitter.

Shukla, serves as Mission Director of National Health Mission in addition to being the Joint Secretary, Health in Chhattisgarh government and is looking after the state's efforts to combat the Covid-19 outbreak.
